comments.text: Hey Neil, explain that most of the fish who die of winterkill dont die from the cold. Or from starvation. They die from suffocation. Plants still grow under the ice in the winter and release oxygen in the winter. As ice gets thicker, and especially if it gets a layer of snow on it, less light passes through to the plants. When photosynthesis slows or stops, the plants stop consuming carbon dioxide and emitting oxygen. Fish then die. There is less oxygen in the lake in winter because there is no oxygen absorption when the lake is iced over. Thats why the photosynthesis of underwater plants is so important. Thats why sometimes the people in charge plow snow off big parts of a lake. Its to increase light transmission, not so ice fishermen can get on the lake easier.

comments.author: @billt8504
comments.text: Fun fact(s): 1) Hydrogen is the only atom that has no protons in its most abundant state.  2)  Hydrogen does come in an isotope that has 1 proton.  3) Two of these Hydrogen isotopes will combine with Oxygen to make water - heavy water.  4)  You can drink it - it's water, but with two extra protons.  5)  If you drink just a sip, you'll be fine.  If you drink a dixie cup (3 oz.) you'll get sick.  If you drink an 8 oz glass of heavy water you will die.  6)  But scientists don't know why you die.  Heavy water and regular water act pretty much the same unless you are playing around with nuclear experiments.  The heavy water does something to the biological cells, but scientists aren't sure what exactly.  Fun facts.

Tyson is well aware of all the fine tuned laws of physics that make life possible and earth a Privileged Planet. He has as much as admitted that the universe is running on software code:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6NkFemtrRZs
And yet he continues to deny the existence of God because he thinks he could do a better job. He illustrates the vast difference between intelligence and wisdom.
Though not a traditional Theist, Albert Einstein approached the subject with far less hubris:
"The human mind, no matter how highly trained, cannot grasp the universe. We are in the position of a little child, entering a huge library whose walls are covered to the ceiling with books in many different tongues. The child knows that someone must have written those books. It does not know who or how. It does not understand the languages in which they are written. The child notes a definite plan in the arrangement of the books, a mysterious order, which it does not comprehend, but only dimly suspects. That, it seems to me, is the attitude of the human mind, even the greatest and most cultured, toward God. We see a universe marvelously arranged, obeying certain laws, but we understand the laws only dimly. Our limited minds cannot grasp the mysterious force that sways the constellations."
